The first thing I noticed - which was never mentioned - were the men's sideburns. No single or married men [at that time] - whether farmer, miner or office worker - kept their hair and sideburns neat at all times. Each of their sideburns (and hair, no doubt) were carefully cut by a barber - perhaps even the same barber - and within 24 hours of the dance.  In my judgement, this dance was a big deal. The haircuts, suits, hats and walking sticks - together indicate this. If this was just "some dance", then there must have been dances frequently - but, I doubt it, given the size of the communities and the lack of access to them.  Yes, one can judge some part of a person's personality from a single photo - but not all parts. This photo was carefully altered by the photographer in the darkroom - to deepen the darkness of their suits and provide alternating shades of gray in the background - to contrast against the black and white details with the men. All elements mentioned were present in the original photo, yet the photographer enhanced these elements to an even more pleasing degree. The net effect of his work is - Art - which all recognize.  There is even more to say about the taking of this photo, particularly in the 1-2 hours before. But the exact details may be undiscoverable. Cheers

Your analysis, though, deals with historical rather than artistic considerations. Sander obviously did not intend this photograph to be a meditation on the horrors of the of a war that had yet to begin or on history. He took this photograph as part of an explicit project to illustrate archetypes of seven categories â€“ and numerous sub-categories â€“ of people into which he divided society. He wanted to â€œspeak the truth in all honesty about our age and the people of our age.â€  No one ever questions why he wanted to do that, or how he expected to do that by taking photos of non-random samples of farmers â€“ or, as you point out, non-farmers. An archetype is a perfect example, and you donâ€™t find an archetype of a farmer by taking a photo of two miners and an office-worker.  As for formal characteristics, you do mention how the horizon runs through the subjectsâ€™ necks, but as indicative of events no one had gone through yet. Thatâ€™s certainly a valid observation, but since the events hadnâ€™t happened yet I suspect that if Sander did that deliberately it was for another reason, a photographic one. The rest of the menâ€™s dark-suited forms sink into their dark background, but their heads stand out against the lighter sky. Perhaps Sander did this to create photographic tension that would make it easier to take in the photograph quickly; in a portrait of three similarly dressed men posed against a similarly dark background the only other tension is with the frame, and thereâ€™s not a lot of that here.  Or maybe his intention was both photographic and thematic â€“ to call attention to the menâ€™s faces to point out that they were individuals despite the mass-produced clothes that make them look like members of a team. That would, however, be inconsistent with his intention to discover archetypes.  Or maybe it was adherence to the rule of thirds, or an accident.   This doesnâ€™t seem to me to be one of his best photographs; itâ€™s too murky for me, and reminds me of advertising for menswear. There is, however, no objective standard of photographic excellence by which to judge my judgment, so I canâ€™t claim that Iâ€™m right or that anyone else is wrong. It just seems to me that a critique of a photograph is better when it includes some discussion of why the photograph was taken (if that is known) and how.
